pros: They provide financial support and you do not have to raise your own funding.
cons: I was part of a team in Central Asia. The team that I joined was less than welcoming and left me alone in my new apartment without any help or support for the first six weeks. I made local friends and friends with other ex-pats and missionaries and created a life in this Muslim country.  Seventeen months after arriving and making a home with little to no help from my “team” , I was informed that I was being removed from my mission country. I was offered a communal women’s room in a guest house in the country where the regional headquarters were located. In short, I was kicked out of my place of service, given three weeks to pack (I had to beg for the second two weeks), and offered a room with strangers in another country. The “management” never talked with me, gave me a solid reason for their actions, or attempted to consider that I had a life or ministry where I was. No other mission assignment was offered. Leadership is poor and women are second class citizens. They never paid the shipping costs to return my worldly goods to America. I returned to America and I will never give this organization a penny of my money. They are corrupt and bloated on the blood of the Lord’s saints. Almost ten years after the event, my experience with the IMB remains a bitter memory.

review_title: I was eager to support the mission but mangement is building their own kingdom.

cons: Downside is management...they are focused on building their own kingdom.  They seem to believe they are "chosen" and can't be wrong.  They are all former missionaries or pastors and have no clue about how to run a $300 million plus budget.  They have no idea how much the staff of the IMB do not trust them.  I do not believe they are malicious but I do believe they are incompetent.  If our contributor knew how money was wasted they would not give.

pros: IMB is filled with passionate people who seek to make the world a better place by sharing the good news of God’s love through Jesus Christ. The home office workplace and global teams include times of prayer, learning and fellowship. Good benefit options for healthcare. Generous vacation allowance. Pleasant workplace typically free of crude or crass behavior. Time-sensitive work supporting thousands of global workers in their daily lives and work. Almost 175 years of history in Richmond.
cons: IMB’s strategies and structure seem to change often to adjust to global needs. Some people find that difficult and experience change fatigue, while others are energized by it — creating tension among coworkers at times. Direct connection to the Southern Baptist Convention means convention theology, issues and restrictions affect decisions in IMB, i.e., no women in senior leadership.

pros: The IMB is a great employer, particularly when it comes to support and benefits. Overall great people, great vision, great mission. Lots of room for lateral movement and trying various roles. The support structure is fantastic and the health benefits are second-to-none. Team members often become your overseas family and you work and socialize together.
cons: High turnover rate of supervisors. Field leadership is often comprised of those who have been around the longest and backed into leadership as opposed to those who are actually skilled at leadership. Limited opportunity to develop professionally. No resources available for transition when you return permanently from overseas. Women often don't have a voice and are aren't always given the same training opportunities as men.

pros: There are none, other than what you make out of your experience personally

-patriarchal- leadership is primarily male and women are often treated as second-rate employees
-lack of concern for safety- they threatened to fire me if I did not comply to a demand which put me in an uncomfortable and what I considered unsafe situation. They do not respect women and do not make attempts to see to their safety/security.
-lack of compassion- those I worked with did not care for the populations they claimed to serve and acted in a judgmental and condescending manner

pros: Working at the imb is the best job i've ever had.  Knowing that you have a kingdom impact and that you're supporting missions worldwide makes it a joy to go to work.  The people here are like family.  The benefits are great - especially the paid-time-off (PTO) structure.  You accrue PTO every pay period, so you never really run out.  Pay is fair.  Flex scheduling is a great benefit to the family (work an extra hour each day, get every other friday or monday off).
cons: Not many cons to working here.  Probably the only con is that it is a bit of a bubble in the sense that there aren't many witnessing opportunities at work, because everyone who works there are believers.  Promotions and bonus are few and far between, but hey, it's a non-profit.

pros: You can feel good about being a part of sharing the gospel around the world and honoring God through your everyday work.
cons: The new administration is streamlining everything, which is good, but at the cost of valuable people. People aren't valued anymore, they're used and then told they're no longer needed. Everything is about David Platt's celebrity status. If you don't belong to a very small network, you will be eliminated.

review_title: There are better ways to serve
pros:
Opportunity to serve
No need to fund raise
cons:
Leadership style and structure is outdated and irrelevant.  New President is a celebrity with a clique of leaders surrounding him.
Field based leadership are mostly people who have no real leadership skills, they just stayed longer than others and move into leadership by longevity.
Most leadership have no real relationships with non-Christians, they simply play church in different countries.

pros: This organization really "gets it" with regards to missions overseas. They are one of the best (financially) supported agencies abroad, have personnel who are committed and who care and have really improved over the last 15 years in their media and marketing strategies to get more folks involved in missions.
cons: All kudos above being stated ... here is where it hits the road. The training is minimal for what you are expected to do on the field. I worked both in the main (home) office and on the field and there was little to NO training available on making a smooth transition between the two areas. Those "back home office way" thought that I knew all I would need to know to be an effective missionary - those "over there" thought that I knew all I would need to know about missions because I had worked in the home office. Both sides were wrong! We were passed over during training sessions ("you all are doing so well, we really need to work with these other folks who are having a hard time right now") and were looked-down-upon by our peers on the field ("oh, you work in the main office? you aren't a real missionary"). Upon our return to the states we have had no contact from our offices, officials, or former colleagues for further work or support. The whole experience was bittersweet. Would I return to the field? definitely! With the IMB? probably not.

pros: This is a sending agency that has been around for a long time. They have all the basic building blocks in place for getting individuals/families in a cross cultural settings.  There were many systems in place to address to assist while on the field.
cons: I suppose this might be both a strength and a weakness. But there was a great deal of change in the 8 plus years I was with the organization. Much of this change was for the better yet there were often kinks in the new systems that either were not worked out or had not when I was still around.

pros: IMB provided a good and fair level of compensation and benefits when compared to other missions agencies.  I did not get rich, for sure.  But I was adequately taken care of.  My fellow employees were great to work with.  Some of the most meaningful and fulfilling experiences of my life took place on the field with IMB.
cons: Since IMB is a religious institution, they are technically exempt from most employment laws including anti-discrimination laws, HIPPA, the Americans with Disabilities Act and unemployment benefits.  Because of the nature of the job work, employees are "on call" 24/7.  One's professional life and one's personal life are one in the same.  In a sense, they own you.  As a result, there is a level of expectation in terms of "success" that is, for the most part, unrealistic and impossible to fulfill in the long run and still maintain any sense of balance in work/family life.  They spread their field personnel out so thin and expect so much, that few employees survive more than ten years.  Those who don't survive and are forced to resign, are treated very unfairly in severence, even when compared to secular employers.  No COBRA insurance is available nor is unemployment compensation.  Most former employees re-enter the US workforce grossly under-employed and struggle financially for many years following overseas employment.

pros: Great work environment. Many long term and faithful employees. Efficient support office serving and supporting working in the EMEA. Good health care and benefits.
cons: High cost of living if working in the London office. The daily slog to work in London traffic. But when you get to work in an old Victoria style office building in the midst of a beautiful English garden, I would slog to work in 3 ft of snow with little complaint.

It's hard to find qualified people in a non-profit.
